TXT.val: This sample uses a C# code to perform the authentication and sign the content.
The C# code is based on the LinkedInOauth.zip file available at:
The C# code in all the Invoke .NET operations has a similar section defining the classes and a specific last function.
It is advised to use an assembly dll for the classes and to define the _oauth object once per the task
(instead of defining everything in every Invoke operation and storing the Tokens in the task)

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\fbidis\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset177 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2509;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\ltrpar\cf1\f0\fs16 The authentication is done as defined at:\par http://developer.linkedin.com/docs/DOC-1008\par \par An empty application was defined in the MSETEST Linkedin account.\par To create an application, simply go to:\par https://www.linkedin.com/secure/developer\par \par The API Key is taken from this application and it will be used for the authentication.\par The authentication is done using a .NET browser control which connects to Linkedin and gets the access token back.\lang1037\f1\rtlch\par \lang1033\b\f0\ltrch\fs20\par }
